story:
Update as of April 23th, 2015: We know that if you are reading this, you are one of several hundred people who can help bring us to our final goal by midnight tonight. We still have plenty of great perks and gifts for our supporters, and if everyone reading this donated $50 right now, or made sure a couple friends  of theirs gave that much today, we would make it past the $16,500 mark. This number is critical because if we can get to that level by this evening we have private donors lined up who will contribute the rest of the fundraising goal and get us to our $30,000 goal that will successfully fund the station through its first year of operation. The campaign ends at midnight tonight, so thanks for your support today! And, remember, Indiegogo allows KVWV to keep ALL donations regardless of if we make our goal, so your support will go to help fund our equipment and facilities REGARDLESS of the final total.

For a peak at some of the radio shows that are airing already and coming to our streaming station check out this facebook album of local shows here and our syndicated programs here. These are the voices we will being to bring to the FM dial in Bellingham and we need YOUR HELP to do it.


New Community Radio is Here!


Make.Shift, Bellingham's non-profit and all-ages downtown art and music venue, is excited to announce that we recently received an FCC license to build a low-power FM community radio station in Bellingham. With the help of radio advocacy group Common Frequency, Make.Shift applied for the license in 2013, during what may have been the last application window ever for low-power FM (LPFM) stations. LPFM are community-based, non-commercial radio stations that operate at 100 watts or less and reach a radius of 3 to 7 miles. Alongside thousands of new stations across the country, we received our license earlier this year and have begun the process of building up the equipment, the staffing and the community volunteers to make this station a success and to empower the community to take ownership over the airwaves.

We are committed to local arts and music and well over half of the music we currently play on our streaming station is local to Bellingham! Our goal is to bring to the local airwaves underrepresented stories, news and culture from our community that does not currently have a home on the FM dial. We want to empower a new generation of DJ's, journalists and local culture enthusiasts to help bring new ideas to the FM dial and to shine a light on what makes Bellingham so special. We are already streaming online and you can hear some of our first local and syndicated programming at http://www.kvwv.org

We need your financial contribution!

Creating a community radio station from scratch is not cheap and involves purchasing a whole host of equipment for the studio and the broadcast site. We have built our budget off of our own 40+ years of collective community radio experiences and models put together by community radio advocates at the national level. In order to fully fund the station and equip ourselves with the necessary gear, from in-studio microphones and mixing boards, to off-site components like our transmitter and antenna, we will need $30,000 more dollars. We have already raised $15,000 over the last several months to get us well on our way but need the support of the Bellingham community to get us fully-funded and broadcasting for the first time at 94.9-FM. Help be a part of the founding of a new community radio station in Bellingham and support KVWV today!

You can always view our current equipment needs and an itemized budget for our first year at our website: http://kvwv.org/donate.php All money that we raise will first and foremost go to the acquiring of the broadcast equipment to get us on the airwaves and then to making our studio as professional sounding as possible. We want our DJ's and community members that visit the station to feel comfortable and at home when they visit and bring their spirit to the station.

Why KVWV needs your voice and support!

Bellingham is blessed to have a thriving independent media scene, with so many local papers and perspectives adding to the dialogue about what makes our town special and how we can improve the community. 94.9 KVWV-FM seeks to fill our airwaves and programming schedule with many of these distinct voices and to put onto the airwaves the community organizations and non-profits that are working at the front lines to make our city more sustainable, resilient and respectful of our diversity of culture and identity. In our video you can see some of the great ideas we have gotten already from community members for locally produced shows, many of those faces hoping to get on the airwaves themselves to cover agricultural issues, youth and elder voices, LGBTQ perspectives, local music, environmental issues, Indigenous perspectives, local government and election coverage, Spanish language programs, local sustainability, comedy and theater, home and gardening tips and much, much more! We will also be a member of the award-winning Pacifica Network and seek to bring syndicated perspectives from across the country and the globe that are compelling for our local community.

Risks & Challenges

Our goal is to be on the air by the end of this year. Starting a new community radio station from the bottom up can be a challenging task and we will need all the help we can get from the community in order to successfully fund the necessary equipment to get on the airwaves. Make.Shift has put together a talented team of non-profit radio advocates, community organizers and folks with non-profit experience who are all committed to empowering the community to get involved and to get their perspectives on the air. We have a firm deadline from the FCC for getting on to the airwaves at 94.9 FM and we have structured our campaign at the committee level, meeting weekly to discuss challenges, successes and next steps. We are open to all new perspectives and enthusiast who want to make this new station a blossoming reality! Come visit us during our office hours, Saturday through Monday from Noon-6pm and email us for more information: http://kvwv.org/contact.php

Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand that making a substantial financial contribution might not be an option for some people. You can help the station in many other ways, first and foremost by sharing this campaign with all of your friends and family and communicating to others why you think it is so important that Bellingham has a new community radio station! Indiegogo has some wonderful sharing tools for you to spread this campaign far and wide and we appreciate all the support you can offer.

We are also searching for community volunteers to come help build the station and create new local programming. If you want to get involved in station development or pitch a show idea to us, visit our website and send us an email! We are having monthly new volunteer orientations and you can always stop by the station during office hours, Saturday to Monday, Noon-6pm, to say hello! We hope to hear from you soon! http://kvwv.org/contact.php

already and coming to our streaming station check out this facebook 
album of local shows here and our syndicated programs here. These are the voices we will being to bring to the FM dial in Bellingham and we need YOUR HELP to do it.New Community Radio is Here!

Make.Shift, Bellingham's non-profit and all-ages downtown art and music venue, is excited to announce that we 
recently received an FCC license to build a low-power FM community radio
 station in Bellingham. With the help of radio advocacy group Common Frequency, 
Make.Shift applied for the license in 2013, during what may have 
been the last application window ever for low-power FM (LPFM) stations. LPFM are community-based, non-commercial 
radio stations that operate at 100 watts or less and reach a radius of 3
 to 7 miles. Alongside thousands of new stations across the country, we received our license earlier this year and have begun the process of building up the equipment, the staffing and the community volunteers to make this station a success and to empower the community to take ownership over the airwaves.
We are committed to local arts and music and well over half of the music we currently play on our streaming station is local to Bellingham! Our goal is to bring to the local airwaves underrepresented stories, news and culture from our community that does not currently have a home on the FM dial. We want to empower a new generation of DJ's, journalists and local culture enthusiasts to help bring new ideas to the FM dial and to shine a light on what makes Bellingham so special. We are already streaming online and you can hear some of our first local and syndicated programming at http://www.kvwv.org
  We need your financial contribution!

Creating a community radio station from scratch is not cheap and involves purchasing a whole host of equipment for the studio and the broadcast site. We have built our budget off of our own 40+ years of collective community radio experiences and models put together by community radio advocates at the national level. In order to fully fund the station and equip ourselves with the necessary gear, from in-studio microphones and mixing boards, to off-site components like our transmitter and antenna, we will need $30,000 more dollars. We have already raised $15,000 over the last several months to get us well on our way but need the support of the Bellingham community to get us fully-funded and broadcasting for the first time at 94.9-FM. Help be a part of the founding of a new community radio station in Bellingham and support KVWV today!
You can always view our current equipment needs and an itemized budget for our first year at our website: http://kvwv.org/donate.php All money that we raise will first and foremost go to the acquiring of the broadcast equipment to get us on the airwaves and then to making our studio as professional sounding as possible. We want our DJ's and community members that visit the station to feel comfortable and at home when they visit and bring their spirit to the station.
  Why KVWV needs your voice and support!
 Bellingham is blessed to have a thriving independent media scene, with so many local papers and perspectives adding to the dialogue about what makes our town special and how we can improve the community. 94.9 KVWV-FM seeks to fill our airwaves and programming schedule with many of these distinct voices and to put onto the airwaves the community organizations and non-profits that are working at the front lines to make our city more sustainable, resilient and respectful of our diversity of culture and identity. In our video you can see some of the great ideas we have gotten already from community members for locally produced shows, many of those faces hoping to get on the airwaves themselves to cover agricultural issues, youth and elder voices, LGBTQ perspectives, local music, environmental issues, Indigenous perspectives, local government and election coverage, Spanish language programs, local sustainability, comedy and theater, home and gardening tips and much, much more! We will also be a member of the award-winning Pacifica Network and seek to bring syndicated perspectives from across the country and the globe that are compelling for our local community.
  Risks & Challenges Our goal is to be on the air by the end of this year. Starting a new community radio station from the bottom up can be a challenging task and we will need all the help we can get from the community in order to successfully fund the necessary equipment to get on the airwaves. Make.Shift has put together a talented team of non-profit radio advocates, community organizers and folks with non-profit experience who are all committed to empowering the community to get involved and to get their perspectives on the air. We have a firm deadline from the FCC for getting on to the airwaves at 94.9 FM and we have structured our campaign at the committee level, meeting weekly to discuss challenges, successes and next steps. We are open to all new perspectives and enthusiast who want to make this new station a blossoming reality! Come visit us during our office hours, Saturday through Monday from Noon-6pm and email us for more information: http://kvwv.org/contact.php 

  Other Ways You Can Help! We understand that making a substantial financial contribution might not be an option for some people. You can help the station in many other ways, first and foremost by sharing this campaign with all of your friends and family and communicating to others why you think it is so important that Bellingham has a new community radio station! Indiegogo has some wonderful sharing tools for you to spread this campaign far and wide and we appreciate all the support you can offer.We are also searching for community volunteers to come help build the station and create new local programming. If you want to get involved in station development or pitch a show idea to us, visit our website and send us an email! We are having monthly new volunteer orientations and you can always stop by the station during office hours, Saturday to Monday, Noon-6pm, to say hello! We hope to hear from you soon! http://kvwv.org/contact.php

story:
Background

About a year ago, we started selling breads and pastries at the Toledo Farmers' Market to see if our uniquely Midwestern interpretations of traditional breads and desserts could find an audience.  We were astounded and humbled by the reaction we received.  Our customers are the most vocal, enthusiastic, supportive bunch of people who ever bit into a croissant.  We simply cannot thank this community enough.  Without all of you, All Crumbs Artisan Bakery simply wouldn't exist.


From the first weeks we came to the Farmers' Market, we have been asked when we would be opening a retail storefront.  We are so very, very close.  But we need your help.


Help Us Help the Hungry


We have a great space on Adams Street in UpTown Toledo.  We have a fantastic kitchen ready to start pumping out mouth-watering creations.  All we need now is the funding to get the licensing process complete and to buy the rest of the equipment needed to scale up production.  We could continue to take it slow, and eventually be able to raise the capital we need, but we can't bear the thought of making everyone wait even longer.  So, we have a plan.

That's where all of you come in, obviously.

We know our customers are going to be loyal visitors to our retail space.  We have no doubts.  So, we are asking you to consider pre-buying some gift certificates for All Crumbs breads and pastries.  We have some great perks set up, all of which let our customers show their support and get their favorites at a discounted price.  

But that's not even the best part.  Once we are open, we want to give it all away again.

Every week as we drive back and forth from the bakery to the Toledo Farmers' Market, we pass something incredible - a small cadre of caring individuals selflessly gathering together to help feed the hungry right in our neighborhood.  Every Saturday, Food for Thought sets up a picnic in Library Square on Adams at Michigan to give away 350 sack lunches to anyone who is hungry.  It makes us want to help.  Through a partnership with Food for Thought, we have made arrangements to donate delicious loaves of our Oatmeal Wheat bread for PB&J sandwiches to be distributed at these weekly picnics.  For every dollar contributed to our campaign, All Crumbs will donate a dollar's worth of bread to Food for Thought, up to $10,000. That's two thousand loaves of bread - enough for 20,000 sandwiches!  

Amazing, right?  That's still not even the best part.

If we make our funding goal and raise the full $10,000, we will make the arrangement permanent so we can donate at least 2,000 loaves every year, for as long as we are open.

Who is Food for Thought?


Food For Thought (FFT) was founded in May of 2007 when a group of people came together through a passion to feed the hungry. They started with feeding eight families per month through a stationary pantry in Oregon, OH and providing 50 sack lunches that were taken to downtown Toledo on Saturday mornings. The downtown picnics have grown in conjunction with other service providers and now 350 lunches are packed every week! 

Food for Thought, now located in downtown Toledo, provides the bulk of their supplemental food assistance via their mobile pantries. Each month they serve an average of 1,000 families or 2,500 people (in 2014 serving 10,722 households which equates to 27,910 individuals). Currently Food for Thought has 24 mobile pantry locations throughout greater Toledo, providing service directly to areas of need. At each site, patrons are able to choose from 10 to 13 different categories of food, including a variety of fresh and healthy foods. Patrons are “shopped through," meaning that they can pick items that they will actually use in their household from options displayed on the pantry shelves. Food For Thought will continue to focus on providing healthier food options for patrons and increasing nutrition education efforts.

story:
The San Antonio Police Department was created by a dozen active, former and retired SAPD officers for the purpose of  honoring the duty and sacrifice of San Antonio police officers from 1846 to the present. It has grown to 3,400 followers. We have the desire and objective to create a museum preserving the history of the department. This fund raising campaign is to increase awareness of the Society both within the department and in the community. We will be represented at as many police oriented events as our volunteers can make it to. The funding provided will allow us to create a kiosk which looks both professional and well planned.
        The funding will be for a 10x15 canopy ($308), an 8 ft. folding table ($66), a   6ft.   folding table ($42), four folding chairs ($66), a table cloth with the SAPD logo ($444), black table cloth covers ($42), reproduction of historical pictures and supplies to explain history ($96) and hinges to support the Alamo stand ($8). Funds raised in excess of $1072 will be used to create posters for substations or cheap promotional items for the kiosk and cover any incidental cost for attending events. If the funding goal is not reached the money will be used for the most important items of the kiosk.
The purposes of the society:

a. The collection and preservation of historical artifacts, records, stories, books, manuscripts, photographs, maps, architectural drawings, and oral histories relating to law enforcement in San Antonio from the first appointed City Marshal in 1847 to the present.

b. To complete interpretive activities to provide exploritative understanding and reassessment of historical events, organizational changes, leadership characterizations, selection and training of officers, and technological improvements of the San Antonio Police Department.

c. The promotion of public respect for and organizational awareness of the San Antonio Police Departments role in the growth, development and service to the city and its citizens.

d. To cooperate with other historical societies, museums, and media to provide assistance in historical understanding of the San Antonio Police Department.

The Society is in the process of becoming a 501 (c) 3 non-profit organization however in order to gauge public support and increase awareness of the effort this fund raising event could not wait for the completion the application. All current board members will have oversight to all funds raised and once non-profit status is reached fund raising will be much more structured.
For those who are unable to donate time managing, researching, handling artifacts or planning, this is the opportunity to support this cause. If you can not donate funds the Society is still fueled by the donation of pictures, artifacts and stories of officers who have served their community. The Society can accept donations of the above listed items for the kiosk rather than funding, but the items must be in good condition and present the appearance necessary to develop faith in the members and the community that the effort is well run and executes its purpose faithfully.

story:
Summary
Hello friends! I am Izzy Yandell and I am working to help bring the arts to students throughout Cheatham County. We are known for being a rural community and that hampers our ability to fully reach out to programs related to the arts, such as dance, film, photography, music, and literature.  Where someone lives shouldn't limit the opportunities they receive! Through this program, I hope students will discover loves and talents that they didn't have before.


What We Need and How You Help

We are hoping to raise around $500. This money is going to be used for taking the children to the Nashville Symphony, The Frist, various theatre productions, music jam sessions, and hopefully a film-related festival. The more we can offer kids at a young age, the more likely they will be to helping future generations. If the monetary budget is not met, the previous proceeds will go to art programs that are in that budget; we will have to make schedule cuts for other trips. The beauty of living in such a tight-knit area is that the lives we touch through this program will be a monumental success for the whole community. And THAT is why this program is paramount for disadvantaged students in Cheatham County.


Other Ways You Can Donate Your Service

If you are not able to help monetarily, I would so appreciate your help in spreading the word with the indiegogo share tools.

story: Help us meet our $4,000 goal. The CAMEROON INITIATIVE represents a handful of Milwaukee organizations coming together with a global mission to install 4 water tanks at SAJOCAH, a rehabilitation center and clinic in Cameroon (W. Africa). The Tertiary Sisters of St. Francis have secured a donation of 4 water tanks, along with funding from three NGOs including Milwaukee’s Feeding Mouths, Filling Minds. The Alverno College Leadership Project for Girls, in collaboration with these organizations, is raising the final $4,000 of the $16,000 project. For more information, visit our website @ www.camerooninitiative.com

story:
Chualong Warrior Tea was started by Chase Chualong, a globe-trotting yogi from New York with a passion for merging ancient wisdom with selfless service.

Disillusioned by city life, he decided to settle in the suburbs of Melbourne, Australia, where he now cultivates his own herbs for his signature tea blends. 

Inspired by the hindu deity Hanuman, he is devoted to sharing the divine knowledge of plants as a path for others to regain our intrinsic connection with earth, our higher selves, and radiant wellbeing. 

He dreams of being able to distribute his blends to a wide range health food stores, while still keeping his integrity intact through growing his own herbs, instead of outsourcing to farmers that may use unethical farming techniques. 

There are three signature blends of Chualong Warrior Tea, corresponding with three of the body’s primary functions; the digestive system, the nervous system and the immune system. 

Subtle and overt levels of stress weakens each of these systems, and leads to various forms of disease and internal disturbance. Constant stimuli, noise pollution, nuerochemical responses to environment, EMF's and interpersonal stressors affect us all. Herbs are a necessary supplement to the modern urban lifestyle. 

Earthy Detox, Chualong’s digestive blend consists of dandelion root, yellow dock, chicory and milk thistle and has an earthy taste very similar to coffee, while promoting your body’s natural ability to cleanse itself. 

Milk thistle has the ability to restore and regenerate liver cells. 

Chicory is full of vitamins and antioxidants. 

Yellow dock is a powerful blood detoxifier. 

Dandelion root is a tonic for the entire digestive system. 

This blend is perfect for a 3-day detox or as a supplement to a cleanse. It’s great for skin, hair, mental clarity, hangovers, heavy metal removal, blood purification, and of course healing and balancing the digestive system.

“Since I’ve incorporated Earthy Detox into my morning routine, I’ve noticed my energy has sustained much longer throughout my workday. While I used to feel sleepy and lethargic after a big meal, I find my body assimilates the food easily and I’m not sleepy until bed time! Definitely hooked!”

-Mantra Mundana, Axis Mundi Catering

With your contribution to Chualong’s IndieGoGo campaign, Chase will be able to:

-Further build out his permaculture-inspired herb garden to be able to cultivate a larger yield, making Chualong Tea available to a wider audience.

-Invest in ethically sourced, eco-friendly packaging for each blend.

-Develop the business end of Chualong Tea to be a fully-sustainable and successful enterprise with a global reach.

We appreciate all forms of helping us build this dream into reality. If you’re unable to contribute financially, we’d greatly appreciate you sharing this campaign with others!

Thanks so much for reading, 

The Chualong Tea Team
